awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  An On-Ramp to Computational Fluency

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

An On-Ramp to Computational Fluency

Overview

This project has developed a learner-friendly, tool-rich programming environment with unprecedented ability to put learners in control of dynamic processes including robots, mathematical models, and games. The project has investigated several models for game-based learning of programming. Technology has been validated primarily through (i) piloting in conjunction with Tertl’s RobotMath prototype curriculum, and (ii) use of the environment by undergraduate interns to develop games and simulations. As a detailed usage case study, and as a first step toward application of the platform for mobile game development, the project developed a mobile game, Swamp Talk, utilizing the project’s technology architecture and featuring strong game customization features.

Intellectual Merit

The Tertl Environment advances the state of the art of novice and non-professional game programming through:

(i)             Further evolution of the structured concurrency programming paradigm, which makes it easier for the programmer to express how processes (such as the behaviors of game elements) should unfold and coordinate over time.

(ii)           A novel user interface for developing, controlling and monitoring computer programs.

(iii)          Integration of programming within an environment that incorporates visual tools, components, and presentation capabilities.

The system has performed well in practical piloting with learners and as an internal development tool.

Broader Impact

Discussions with potential partners for commercialization of the technology began during the award period, and are continuing.

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2011
Modified by: Christopher M Hancock
